byline.original: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and RICK GLADSTONE
byline.contributor: David D. Kirkpatrick reported from Tripoli, and Rick Gladstone from New York. Adam Nossiter contributed reporting from Tripoli.

abstract: Interim Libyan leader Mustafa Abdel-Jalil announces that he has asked NATO to prolong its air patrols through 2011 and add military advisers on the ground, despite his government's declaration of liberation after the death of Col Muammar el-Qaddafi, citing the possibility of Qaddafi loyalists forces regrouping and causing trouble.
snippet: A request for an extension of NATO help suggested Libya’s interim government is concerned that remnants of Colonel Muammar el-Qaddafi’s defeated forces could regroup and cause new trouble.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

lead_paragraph: A request for an extension of NATO help suggested Libya’s interim government is concerned that remnants of Colonel Muammar el-Qaddafi’s defeated forces could regroup and cause new trouble.

headline.main: Libya’s Interim Leader Asks NATO to Stay Through the End of 2011
headline.print_headline: Libya’s Interim Leader Asks NATO to Stay Through the End of 2011
headline.seo: Libya Leader Wants NATO Presence Through 2011
